JAPAN

Honda (7267 JT)
- Co. is targeting global sales at 5.4mln units for this year. (Newswires)

Itochu (8001 JT)
- Co. is to acquire Alta Forest Products for around JPY 30bln. (Newswires)

Mazda (7261 JT)
- Co. is to offer a new engine later this year which will be 30% more efficient than standard engines. (Nikkei)

Nomura (8604 JT)
- Co. President signalled a shake-up of its Japanese and US research operations. (Newswires)

SoftBank (9984 JT)
- Co. is said to be seeking an IPO which could be valued at USD 18bln for its mobile unit as soon as this Spring, although Co. said that listing is an option and that no decision has been made yet. (Newswires)
- Co. to pay EUR 460mln for a 20% stake in German online car dealer Auto1. (FT)

Toshiba (6502 JT)
- Co. sale of Westinghouse stake could provide it with an additional JPY 200bln tax deduction in FY17. (Nikkei)

Other News
- BoJ looks likely to raise its FY 18 growth outlook at next week’s board meeting, according to reports. (Nikkei)

 

SOUTH KOREA

Hyundai Motor (005380 KS)
- Co. US chief sees SUVs to increase to 50% of its US sales vs. 38% during 2017. (Newswires)

- Co. venture with Daewoo is to widen SME’s project with Incheon. (newswires)

- Co. is said to consider building a 4th plant in 2019. (Newswires)

Samsung Electronics (005930 KS)
- Co. expanded cooperation with North American retailers to bolster up sales of home appliances in the region. (Yonhap)

Other News
- Korea Institute for Industrial Economics and Trade said that South Korea's manufacturing sector is said to be anticipating tougher times during Q1. (Yonhap)

PRE-MARKET AUSTRALIAN STOCK NEWS: BHP is seeking USD 1bln for its Samarco stake; Energy sector outperformed in US on Friday as oil rose over 1%
content:
Ardent Leisure (AAD AT)
- Co. is expected to announce a US-based CEO. (The Australian)

BHP (BHP AT)
- Co. is asking for USD 1.0bln from Vale for its 50% stake in the Samarco JV. (AFR)

Perseus Mining (PRU AT)
- Co. said that first gold output is expected ahead of schedule for its Sissingue gold mine. (Newswires)

Vocus Communications (VOC AT)
- Co. is to split its Australian enterprise and wholesale units into 2 operating segments. (Newswires)

Basic Materials / Energy
- Spot gold rose 1.2%.
- WTI crude rose 1.1%.

subject: UK Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson is said to have warned allies that Brexit is far from certain
ASIAN DAILY ECONOMIC RELEASES CALENDAR NOW AVAILABLE IN THE RESEARCH SECTION: Highlights Include  Japanese Money Supply and Machine Tool Orders, Australian TD Securities Inflation, US holiday
DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

Chinese New Yuan Loans (CNY)(Dec) 584.4B vs. Exp. 1000.0B (Prev. 1120.0B). (Newswires)
Chinese Aggregate Financing (CNY)(Dec) 1140B vs. Exp. 1500B (Prev. 1600.0B)
Chinese Money Supply M2 (Dec) Y/Y 8.2% vs. Exp. 9.2% (Prev. 9.1%); record low

South Korean Export Prices (Dec) Y/Y -2.1% (Prev. 2.5%). (Newswires)
South Korean Import Prices (Dec) Y/Y -1.0% (Prev. 3.9%)

New Zealand Food Price Index (Dec) M/M -0.8% (Prev. -0.4%)

 

UK

Spain and the UK set to hold talks regarding Gibraltar following Brexit, according to press reports. (Newswires)

The Dutch Finance Minister said on Friday that there was no new agreement between Spain and Netherlands on British departure from EU, which followed reports that the 2 European nation’s were seeking a soft Brexit deal. (Newswires)


EU

Germany SPD party leaders said they will seek to push for improvement on a coalition agreement with German Chancellor Merkel’s conservatives. (Newswires)

S&P affirmed Belgium ratings at 'AA/A-1+'; Outlook Stable. (Newswires)

DBRS confirmed Italy at BBB (high); Stable Trend. (Newswires)

 

US

Fed's Rosengren (Non-Voter, Soft Hawk) said more than three 2018 hikes are likely and that Fed should consider updating policy framework in which an inflation range of 1.5%-3.0% might be appropriate. (Newswires)

Fed’s Kashkari (Non-Voter, Dove) said he hopes inflation is moving reliably towards target and that he would like to see more data. (Newswires)

Fed's Harker (Non-Voter, Soft Hawk) repeated that he expects 2 rate hikes in 2018. (Newswires)

US President Trump commented via Twitter that he doesn’t believe Democrats want a deal on immigration and are all talk and no action, while he added that a great opportunity has been missed. However, there were also reports that suggested some Republicans were still hopeful regarding a possible DACA deal. (Twitter/Newswires)

Data Recap
US CPI MM, SA (Dec) 0.1% vs. Exp. 0.2% (Prev. 0.4%). (Newswires)
US CPI YY, NSA (Dec) 2.1% vs. Exp. 2.1% (Prev. 2.2%)
US Core CPI YY, NSA (Dec) 1.8% vs. Exp. 1.7% (Prev. 1.7%)
US Retail Sales MM (Dec) 0.4% vs. Exp. 0.4% (Prev. 0.8%, Rev. 0.9%)


COMMODITIES

US Baker Hughes Total (12 Jan) 939 (Prev. 924). (Newswires)

Nigeria’s Oil Minister said that we shouldn’t get too bullish or excited yet regarding oil price increase and that things can change overnight. (Newswires)  

Reports stated that Iraq, UAE, Qatar and Oman were all calling for OPEC and Non-OPEC producers to stick to the output cut deal. (Newswires)
 

MARKET RECAP

The equities rally continued, with major US bourses printing fresh record highs at the end of the week, as Q4 earnings season gets underway. Banks began reporting their numbers, with JPMorgan reporting a top and bottom-line beat; Wells Fargo, however, could only beat on the Adj EPS front, with revenues falling slightly short of expectations. The former’s trading revenues were glum, as expected, with fixed income trading off by over 30%, while equities trading revenues were flat. Consumer discretionary led the gains after retail sales increased. Energy was also higher, tracking crude prices. On the other end of the scale, utilities were the laggard, once again. SPX +0.66% at 2786, DJI +0.88% at 25800, NDX +0.75% at 6758

Top performers: Consumer cyclicals +1.0%, Energy +0.8%, Industrials +0.7%
Bottom sectors: Utilities -0.4%, Consumer non-cyclicals +0.1%, Materials +0.1%


Although Treasury yields were slightly higher on the day (with the exception of 30s, which were unchanged), major curves flattened; most notably, the 2s30s curve, by c.3.6bps. 2s yields rose by around 3bps on the day following a decent core CPI data print, which has nudged the probability of three Fed hikes in 2018 slightly higher. Corporate supply had been healthy for the week, with high-grade raising $32bln, according to Reuters. US 10-Year T-Note Futures settle 6 ticks lower at 122-30.

subject: ASIA-PAC SERVICE IS NOW LIVE FOR TODAY'S SESSION
